overview: Massachusetts v. EPA Supreme Court Ruling
furtherDescription: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled that greenhouse gases are air pollutants under the Clean Air Act and that the EPA has authority to regulate them if they endanger public health or welfare. The decision established legal standing for federal regulation of climate pollutants.

overview: American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA) — clean energy spending
furtherDescription: The stimulus package included substantial funding for clean energy deployment, grid modernisation, energy efficiency and low-carbon technology R&D — widely credited with accelerating early 2010s renewable growth in the United States.

overview: EPA Endangerment Finding for Greenhouse Gases
furtherDescription: The EPA issued the final Endangerment and Cause or Contribute Findings under the Clean Air Act, concluding that six greenhouse gases threaten public health and welfare — a scientific and legal basis for subsequent federal regulation.

overview: Obama Administration Announces Clean Power Plan
furtherDescription: The EPA unveiled the Clean Power Plan setting the first federal limits on carbon pollution from power plants, with state-specific targets and mechanisms to shift generation toward lower-emitting sources. The rule became a central plank of US climate policy despite later legal and political challenges.

The United States formally signed the Paris Agreement at the UN signing ceremony in New York, committing to international cooperation on limiting global temperature rise and to submit an emissions reduction pledge under the Agreement.

overview: President Trump Announces Intention to Withdraw from Paris Agreement
furtherDescription: President Trump declared the United States would withdraw from the Paris Agreement, signalling a major federal retreat from the international climate framework; the formal withdrawal process concluded on 4 November 2020.

overview: Safer Affordable Fuel-Efficient (SAFE) Vehicles Rule (national vehicle standards)
furtherDescription: NHTSA and EPA finalised the SAFE rule establishing weaker federal fuel economy and CO₂ standards for model years 2021–2026 and taking steps to narrow California's ability to set stricter vehicle emissions rules — a federal rollback of vehicle climate standards.

The Trump-era EPA finalised the ACE rule to replace the Clean Power Plan with a narrower approach focused on heat-rate improvements at individual coal units — widely criticised for delivering substantially smaller emissions reductions.

overview: California Executive Order: Zero-emission new car sales by 2035
furtherDescription: California issued Executive Order N-79-20 setting a target that all new passenger cars and trucks sold in the state be zero-emission vehicles by 2035, demonstrating ambitious subnational action that contrasts with federal policy shifts.

overview: President Biden Signs Instrument to Rejoin the Paris Agreement
furtherDescription: On his first day in office President Biden signed an instrument to rejoin the Paris Agreement; the United States' re-entry took effect on 19 February 2021, signalling a rapid federal reversal of the prior administration's withdrawal.

overview: United States Announces New NDC: 50–52% Reduction by 2030
furtherDescription: President Biden announced an updated nationally determined contribution under the Paris Agreement committing the United States to reduce net greenhouse gas emissions by 50–52% below 2005 levels by 2030.

President Biden revoked the cross-border permit for the Keystone XL pipeline on his first day in office; the pipeline project was subsequently cancelled by its owner in June 2021, a high-profile setback for an oil infrastructure project opposed by climate and indigenous groups.

overview: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (Bipartisan Infrastructure Law)
furtherDescription: The IIJA provided historic funding for grid resilience, electric vehicle charging infrastructure, public transit and other measures that support decarbonisation and adaptation — representing major bipartisan infrastructure investment with climate-relevant provisions.

overview: U.S. Supreme Court: West Virginia v. EPA limits EPA regulatory reach
furtherDescription: The Supreme Court ruled that the EPA could not rely on broad 'generation-shifting' authority under Section 111(d) of the Clean Air Act without clear congressional authorisation, constraining one route for wide-ranging federal power to reduce power-sector emissions.

overview: Inflation Reduction Act Signed — largest federal climate investment
furtherDescription: The Inflation Reduction Act authorised the single largest US federal investment in climate and energy, with extensive tax credits, grants and programmes to accelerate clean energy, manufacturing, electrification and emissions reductions.

Following the revocation of its presidential permit and persistent legal and political opposition, TC Energy announced cancellation of the Keystone XL pipeline project; the decision was hailed by climate activists and critics of fossil-fuel expansion.

overview: Federal Vehicle and Fuel-standards Preemption and Rulemaking (SAFE / One National Program)
furtherDescription: The administration and federal agencies moved to establish a single national vehicle emissions and fuel economy programme, limiting state waivers and harmonising standards at a lower stringency than earlier federal rules — a contentious shift with climate implications.

overview: State and Local Climate Leadership Increases (multiple actions)
furtherDescription: In response to uneven federal action, US states, cities and businesses accelerated commitments on renewables, emissions targets and climate policy (for example regional RGGI expansion, corporate net-zero pledges and state NDC-aligned targets), creating a parallel track of subnational ambition.

overview: Federal clean-energy rulemaking and litigation volatility
furtherDescription: Between 2015 and 2022 the US experienced rapid swings in federal climate policy — from ambitious rules (Clean Power Plan) to rollbacks (ACE, SAFE) and judicial limits (West Virginia v. EPA) — producing regulatory uncertainty affecting long-term decarbonisation pathways.
